Two very different Faiths. CNN mixed up Faith Evans with Faith Hill on Twitter on Friday, February 3, and the internet was quick to point out the mistake. Faith Hill is releasing an album of duets with The Notorious B.I.G, 20 years after his murder https://t.co/AFZrE2RnjG pic.twitter.com/XBzxS8wejv ‚Äî CNN (@CNN) February 3, 2017 
The news outlet tweeted a split photo of Evans, 43, and her late husband, Notorious B.I.G., who was murdered in a still-unsolved 1997 drive-by shooting in L.A. ‚ÄúFaith Hill is releasing an album of duets with The Notorious B.I.G, 20 years after his murder,‚Äù the caption read, naming the country star instead of the R&B icon. (The name was correct in the actual article.) 
About 10 minutes later, CNN realized its error and issued a correction, but it has left up the original tweet. Evans even responded to the gaffe by retweeting the Faith Hill tweet with a pair of eyes emoji . The ‚ÄúBreathe‚Äù singer, 49, was on board for the idea, though, writing , ‚ÄúThis sounds awesome!‚Äù Correction: Faith *Evans is releasing an album of duets with The Notorious B.I.G, 20 years after his murder https://t.co/AFZrE2RnjG pic.twitter.com/lTYfCsBUU6 ‚Äî CNN (@CNN) February 3, 2017 
Evans, who shares a 20-year-old son, Christopher Wallace Jr ., with the late rapper, has recorded a new album, The King & I , that features both well-known and unreleased verses from Biggie. The album is out May 19 in honor of what would have been Biggie‚Äôs 45th birthday. The Notorious B.I.G. in 1995. Chris Walter/WireImage 
Fans of all three musicians dragged the news organization on social media for blunder. ‚ÄúHey @CNN mixing up Faith Hill and Faith Evans means you need to hire more black people. #inclusionmatters,‚Äù one person tweeted.
